description: It shows someone enthusiastically jumping up and down with both arms raised, exclaiming “Yippee!”—essentially celebrating something or reacting with excitement in a crowd. The gesture and the text convey a triumphant or happy moment.

response.content: I am ai and gif professor.
arc is types of Abtract Reasoning Corpus, and you are professor. I should say things clearly and without fakes at all.

content.text: Hi GPT, can you explain this gif ?

response.content: It shows someone enthusiastically jumping up and down with both arms raised, exclaiming “Yippee!”—essentially celebrating something or reacting with excitement in a crowd. The gesture and the text convey a triumphant or happy moment.

So, this is gif, so time-series image data. Can you under-size the image by 30x30? grid style. You may know how Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus look like. You can follow that style, but no input-output pair, but image1 -> image2 -> image 3 -> image n  (each image has same size of grid 30x30) just show me the first image (it can be represented as array)
Then, can you give me the highlight part of the pixelated gif with same 30x30 grid , you can provide me the matrix as well as generating image if you want.

Below is a purely illustrative numeric grid focusing on the “highlight” section (e.g., raised arms) in a 30×30 pixel-style downscale. Each row has 30 symbolic values (0–9) that loosely represent color or intensity; they are not exact pixel data but are meant to give a sense of how the arm area might look in a coarse grid. No mention (or detail) of any blurred face is included.

This kind of layout simply marks a rough “highlight” section (arms raised). You could treat each cell’s value as an approximate placeholder for color/brightness in that spot.

Below is a self‐contained ARC‐style puzzle, fitting within a 10×10 grid. It has three training examples (each with an input grid and the corresponding output grid) plus one test example (with both input and output grids). The consistent “rule” that solves all four examples is:  
• Recolor the four corner cells of the grid to color 9.  

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
1. ARC‐LIKE TASK
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

Training Pair 1  
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Input (3×3):  
[
  [2, 2, 2],
  [2, 5, 2],
  [1, 2, 2]
]

Output (3×3):  
[
  [9, 2, 9],
  [2, 5, 2],
  [9, 2, 9]
]
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Training Pair 2  
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Input (4×4):  
[
  [1, 0, 0, 2],
  [3, 5, 5, 2],
  [7, 5, 5, 1],
  [7, 0, 0, 1]
]

Output (4×4):  
[
  [9, 0, 0, 9],
  [3, 5, 5, 2],
  [7, 5, 5, 1],
  [9, 0, 0, 9]
]
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Training Pair 3  
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Input (5×5):  
[
  [1, 1, 8, 8, 0],
  [2, 7, 7, 7, 0],
  [3, 7, 9, 7, 1],
  [3, 7, 7, 7, 2],
  [0, 1, 1, 8, 8]
]

Output (5×5):  
[
  [9, 1, 8, 8, 9],
  [2, 7, 7, 7, 0],
  [3, 7, 9, 7, 1],
  [3, 7, 7, 7, 2],
  [9, 1, 1, 8, 9]
]
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Test Pair (to verify the rule)  
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Input (5×5):  
[
  [2, 2, 2, 2, 2],
  [2, 1, 5, 1, 2],
  [2, 1, 5, 1, 2],
  [2, 1, 5, 1, 2],
  [2, 2, 2, 2, 2]
]

Output (5×5):  
[
  [9, 2, 2, 2, 9],
  [2, 1, 5, 1, 2],
  [2, 1, 5, 1, 2],
  [2, 1, 5, 1, 2],
  [9, 2, 2, 2, 9]
]
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
2. ANALOGY: “RECOLOR THE FOUR CORNERS TO 9”
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
All grids share the same transformation: Identify the four corner cells (upper‐left, upper‐right, lower‐left, lower‐right), then paint them with color 9, leaving the rest unchanged.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
3. A POSSIBLE SOLUTION IN HODEL’S DSL
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Below is an example function that implements the transformation using the provided DSL definitions. It takes a grid, finds its corners, and fills them with color 9. The key steps:  
• Convert the entire grid into an object (asobject).  
• Extract the set of corner indices (corners).  
• Use fill to repaint those corner indices with color 9.  

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
from arc_types import Grid
from arc_types import asobject, corners, fill

def corner_fill(grid: Grid) -> Grid:
    """
    Recolor the four corner cells in the grid to color 9.
    """
    # 1) Convert the full grid into an object.
    grid_obj = asobject(grid)
    
    # 2) Retrieve the four corners (indices) of that object.
    corner_indices = corners(grid_obj)
    
    # 3) Fill those positions with color 9.
    return fill(grid, 9, corner_indices)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Using this logic on each input grid yields the shown output grids, matching all three training examples and the test example.
